annotation.summary: Describes how to use the Raise a Shield action, including hand requirements and exceptions for specific shield types such as compact, irising, and phase shields. The benefits of the action are lost if the hand no longer meets the required conditions or if the shield is not deployed when necessary.
annotation.action_economy: 1 action
annotation.prerequisites: Must be holding or have a free hand for a shield; irising or phase shields must be deployed to use this action.

annotation.summary: When you have the Shield Block reaction, you can use it while Raising your Shield to reduce incoming damage by the shield's Hardness. Any remaining damage is applied to both you and the shield.
annotation.action_economy: Reaction (triggered while Raising a Shield)
annotation.prerequisites: Access to the Shield Block reaction from a class feature or feat

annotation.summary: Shields use the same core statistics as armor—Price, Speed Penalty, and Bulk—referencing page 245 for details, with additional shield-specific statistics described separately.
Explains that a shield’s damage is reduced by its Hardness value, which is important when using the Shield Block feat. References where to find related rules.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this rule describes a passive effect rather than an action.
annotation.prerequisites: Requires a shield; interaction with the Shield Block feat for full use.

annotation.summary: Explains that the shield's Hit Points (HP) and Broken Threshold (BT) indicate how much damage it can take before becoming broken or destroyed, which is relevant when using the Shield Block reaction.
annotation.action_economy: reaction
annotation.prerequisites: Must be using a shield capable of the Shield Block reaction.

annotation.summary: A shield may be used as a martial melee weapon for attacks using the shield bash statistics, but only if it was not specifically designed as a weapon. Shields cannot receive armor or weapon upgrades.
annotation.action_economy: Attack action (using shield bash)
annotation.prerequisites: Must be wielding a non-weapon shield

annotation.summary: An archaic shield is made with traditional materials and methods, making it ineffective against modern weaponry, though it still interacts normally with shield runes from Pathfinder.
annotation.action_economy: none
annotation.prerequisites: must be a shield with the archaic trait

annotation.summary: Describes how certain shields can be installed as armor or weapon upgrades, allowing them to function like normal shields when raised. Only weapons with the parry trait can have a shield installed.
annotation.action_economy: Requires the same action as Raise a Shield to activate the installed shield.
annotation.prerequisites: Weapon must have the parry trait to install a shield upgrade.

annotation.summary: A table listing various commercial shields, detailing their level, price, AC bonus, speed penalty, bulk, hardness, hit points, and traits. Shields include carbon, compact, deflecting field, irising, mobile bulwark, phase, and riot models, with differences in analog or tech traits, retractable or hefty properties, and varying defensive bonuses.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; these are equipment items providing passive or situational bonuses rather than requiring actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None explicitly stated; availability may depend on character level or access to commercial-grade equipment.

annotation.summary: A table listing armor or equipment grade upgrades by level, showing the required level, additional cost, total value, and improvements to hardness, hit points, and broken threshold for each grade from Commercial to Paragon.
annotation.action_economy: None (applies during item creation or upgrade process, not in combat)
annotation.prerequisites: Character or crafter must meet the listed grade level requirement and pay the associated credit cost.

annotation.summary: The paragraph describes the variety of shield types available, emphasizing that designer and customized versions exist to suit personal aesthetics, including shields with decorative or visual effects.
annotation.action_economy: None
annotation.prerequisites: None

annotation.summary: A phase shield is a wearable technological device that generates a protective hardlight barrier when activated. It is durable, customizable in color and imagery, and often worn on a limb or belt.
annotation.action_economy: Requires an action or similar activation to deploy the hardlight barrier (exact timing depends on system rules).
annotation.prerequisites: Access to technological equipment or proficiency with advanced gear, depending on game system.

annotation.summary: A riot shield made from transparent aluminum and nanocarbon-reinforced polymers, providing durable protection for the wielder.
annotation.action_economy: Typically used as part of a defensive or guard action; may require one hand to wield.
annotation.prerequisites: Proficiency with shields or relevant training to use defensive gear effectively.

annotation.summary: Describes shields designed for use in tight formations, sometimes made transparent for beginners to see through, though experienced warriors rely on skill rather than visibility as the material quickly becomes opaque with damage.
annotation.action_economy: Passive; applies while the shield is raised or used in formation.
annotation.prerequisites: Proficiency with shields or training in formation fighting.

annotation.summary: Ranged weapons typically do not add an attribute modifier to damage, except thrown weapons, which use the Strength modifier. Higher-level characters can gain additional damage through weapon specialization and improved weapon versions.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; describes damage calculation rather than an action.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have a ranged or thrown weapon; higher-level benefits require weapon specialization or improved weapon versions.

annotation.summary: Only the weapon's base damage die is used when calculating effects that depend on the number of damage dice; additional dice from other sources are excluded.
annotation.action_economy: none
annotation.prerequisites: A weapon with a defined damage die.

annotation.summary: When an effect increases your weapon damage die size, replace your normal die with the next larger die (e.g., d4 → d6). If you already use a d12, it cannot increase further, and you can only apply this increase once.
annotation.action_economy: none
annotation.prerequisites: An effect or ability that instructs you to increase your weapon damage die size.

annotation.summary: The paragraph introduces the weapon tables, which list statistics for different melee and ranged weapons available for purchase, and explains that these tables present specific weapon statistics.
annotation.action_economy: none
annotation.prerequisites: none

annotation.summary: Describes how many Interact actions are required to reload a ranged weapon, noting that some may require no separate reload action and that multi-action reloads may be treated as a single activity or split across turns at the GM's discretion.
annotation.action_economy: Reloading requires a specified number of Interact actions (0 or more). If 2+ actions are needed, the GM decides if they must be consecutive or can be split across turns.
annotation.prerequisites: Possession of a ranged weapon that requires reloading; GM adjudication for multi-action reloads.

annotation.summary: Describes how ranged weapons store and use ammunition, including magazines for physical ammo, batteries for energy weapons, and chemicals for certain weapon types. Explains that battery-powered weapons use charges based on battery capacity and compatible grades.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified; focuses on ammunition capacity and compatibility rather than actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None explicitly stated; assumes access to appropriate ammunition or power source for the weapon.

annotation.summary: Describes how tanks act as batteries for chemical weapons, which cannot be recharged and must be replaced after use. Projectile weapons use magazines that hold a limited number of projectiles, which serve as ammunition. The type of projectile varies by weapon type, and ammunition must be purchased separately at a rate of 10 projectiles per credit.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified; relates to equipment management rather than combat actions.
annotation.prerequisites: Requires access to compatible weapon and sufficient credits to purchase ammunition.

annotation.summary: Describes how ammunition is consumed when making ranged Strikes with a weapon, reducing the magazine by a specified amount each time it is fired. Some abilities may reference this ammo expenditure as part of their requirements.
annotation.action_economy: Varies depending on the action that uses the weapon or ability; typically part of a ranged Strike.
annotation.prerequisites: Requires a weapon that uses ammunition and has a defined expend value.

annotation.summary: A heading introducing a section likely detailing rules or guidelines for managing valuable or limited ammunition and weapons within the game.

The Deadly trait increases a weapon's damage on a critical hit by adding extra damage dice of a specified size, rolled after doubling the base damage. Higher-grade weapons gain more dice, and the deadly die size is unaffected by effects that alter normal weapon damage dice.
annotation.action_economy: Passive effect triggered on a critical hit
annotation.prerequisites: Weapon must have the Deadly trait; effect scales with weapon grade (elite, ultimate, paragon)

annotation.summary: The Forceful trait increases a weapon’s damage when used multiple times in the same turn, granting escalating circumstance bonuses to damage based on the number of weapon damage dice.
annotation.action_economy: Applies to multiple attacks made during the same turn; no additional actions required.
annotation.prerequisites: Must make more than one attack with the same weapon in a turn.

annotation.summary: A section heading introducing rules or guidelines related to valuable or limited ammunition and weapons.
Weapons with the Razing trait deal extra damage to objects, structures, and vehicles, adding damage equal to twice the number of weapon damage dice.
annotation.action_economy: applies when dealing damage with the weapon; no additional action required
annotation.prerequisites: must be using a weapon with the Razing trait

annotation.summary: The Thrown trait allows a weapon to be used for ranged attacks. When thrown, it counts as a ranged weapon, and the attacker adds their Strength modifier to damage as if it were a melee attack. Melee weapons with this trait specify a range increment, while ranged weapons use their listed range increment.
annotation.action_economy: Standard attack action or equivalent for making a ranged attack.
annotation.prerequisites: Must be wielding a weapon with the Thrown trait.

annotation.summary: Twin weapons grant a damage bonus when used together. If you attack with one and then attack with another of the same type in the same turn, you add a circumstance bonus to the damage equal to the weapon’s number of damage dice.
annotation.action_economy: Requires at least two attacks within the same turn using different weapons of the same type.
annotation.prerequisites: Must wield two weapons of the same type; both must have the Twin trait.

annotation.summary: A weapon with the Two-Hand trait can be used with both hands to increase its damage die to the specified value, affecting all damage dice rolled for that weapon.
annotation.action_economy: No additional actions required; applies when choosing to wield the weapon with two hands.
annotation.prerequisites: Must have a weapon with the Two-Hand trait and use both hands to wield it.

annotation.summary: When you score a critical hit with an axe, you can deal extra damage to a nearby creature if your attack roll exceeds its AC. The damage equals the weapon’s base damage dice result, without doubling or bonuses.
annotation.action_economy: Triggered on a critical hit; no additional action required.
annotation.prerequisites: Must be wielding an axe and score a critical hit on an adjacent target.

annotation.summary: The Sniper feature increases the damage dealt to a target by adding 2 extra points for each weapon damage die rolled.
annotation.action_economy: passive
annotation.prerequisites: Requires use of a weapon that rolls damage dice.

annotation.summary: The Arc Pistol is a firearm that uses an internal capacitor to discharge electrical arcs instead of firing physical ammunition. It features an insulated synthetic stock, typically marked with a high-voltage symbol.
annotation.action_economy: Used as a standard attack action when fired.
annotation.prerequisites: Requires proficiency with pistols or energy weapons, depending on the game system.

annotation.summary: A section heading likely introducing rules or guidelines about valuable or limited ammunition and weapons within the game.
A semi-automatic pistol that automatically ejects spent cartridges and chambers a new round after each shot.
annotation.action_economy: One attack action per shot; reloading handled automatically after each shot.
annotation.prerequisites: Proficiency with firearms or pistols as defined by the game system.

annotation.summary: A Zero Pistol is a ranged weapon that fires supercooled liquid stored in transparent canisters as its ammunition.
annotation.action_economy: Standard attack action to fire
annotation.prerequisites: Proficiency with pistols or equivalent weapon training

annotation.summary: Guides players to choose weapons they are trained in, compare options for best attack modifiers, and select both melee and ranged weapons for versatility.
annotation.action_economy: None
annotation.prerequisites: Character must know which weapon types they are trained or better in.

annotation.summary: A section heading likely introducing rules or guidelines about valuable or limited ammunition and weapons within the game.
A magnetic rifle that uses coils to accelerate projectiles with enhanced power and precision.
annotation.action_economy: Standard attack action to fire.
annotation.prerequisites: Proficiency with ranged or advanced firearms.

annotation.summary: The Card Slinger is a ceramic weapon that launches sharpened playing cards, designed for stealth and infiltration. It is particularly effective in the hands of someone skilled with cards or familiar with their flight paths.
annotation.action_economy: Standard attack action to fire a card projectile.
annotation.prerequisites: Proficiency with ranged weapons or specialized training in card-based weaponry.

annotation.summary: This paragraph lists a variety of melee and thrown weapons from a tabletop role-playing game, detailing their levels, prices, damage types, traits, and special properties. Each weapon entry includes information such as whether it is powered, analog, modular, or tech-based, along with specific combat traits like finesse, reach, trip, or deadly. The section serves as a reference for players and game masters to select and compare weapons based on their mechanical characteristics and intended use in combat.
annotation.action_economy: Not directly specified; these are equipment entries used during attacks or combat actions depending on the weapon’s traits.
annotation.prerequisites: Varies by weapon; some require proficiency with specific weapon groups (e.g., sword, axe, polearm) or access to powered/tech equipment.

annotation.summary: A table listing various simple ranged weapons, including pistols, rifles, and other firearms. Each entry provides details such as level, price, damage type, range, reload time, bulk, hands required, ammunition type, and special traits. The weapons cover multiple energy and projectile types (acid, electric, kinetic, laser, sonic, cryo) and include both analog and technological variants.
annotation.action_economy: Varies by weapon; typically requires one action to attack and additional actions to reload depending on the reload value.
annotation.prerequisites: Proficiency with simple ranged weapons or specific weapon group training as required by the game system.

annotation.summary: The Arc Emitter is a commercial-level ranged weapon that deals 1d8 electricity damage at a range of 20 feet. It uses a magazine with 10 charges and has traits indicating it is nonlethal, creates a cone-shaped shock area, is unwieldy, and is technological in nature.
annotation.action_economy: Standard attack action to fire; reload requires one action.
annotation.prerequisites: Proficiency with martial ranged weapons; access to technological equipment.

annotation.summary: A progression table outlining weapon improvement grades from Commercial to Paragon, showing level requirements, upgrade costs, total value, damage dice increases, and tracking bonuses. Each grade enhances weapon performance and traits at escalating credit costs.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section describes item upgrades rather than combat actions.
annotation.prerequisites: Requires a base Commercial-grade weapon; higher-grade upgrades require meeting the listed level and paying the associated credit cost.

annotation.summary: The paragraph lists different types of ammunition and batteries used as consumable items in a tabletop role-playing game. It includes projectile ammunition and various battery types (commercial and tactical), along with their associated statistics such as level, price, magazine capacity, and bulk.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section describes items rather than actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; these items can typically be purchased or found as standard equipment.

annotation.summary: A list of chem tank ammunition items with varying levels, prices, magazine capacities, and bulk values, ranging from commercial to elite models.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this entry describes equipment statistics rather than an action.
annotation.prerequisites: None; these items can be purchased or equipped if available.
